Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Mobile Content Sharing Networks: Theory to Implementation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The last few years have witnessed an explosive growth in the popularity and capabilities of mobile handheld devices such as smart-phones, tablets, and laptops. The rapidly expanding computational power of these portable devices has enabled their users to access, process, and share content anytime, anywhere. However, these devices have already put significant stress on many of today's 3G/4G cellular networks, which, if left unaddressed, will result in increasingly poor quality-of-service and user experience in the future.

To address this problem, the project investigates how to exploit the key attributes of mobile content sharing environments to dramatically increase network performance. Preliminary studies show that jointly utilizing the wireless channel and mobility can yield greater gains than even the sum of exploiting mobility and the channel independently. In this case, the whole is greater than the sum of its parts! Thus, the main focus of this research is to (i) develop the analytical foundation for double opportunism - i.e., joint exploitation of the wireless channel and mobility-considering the practical realities of the wireless environment for content distribution networks; (ii) develop low-complexity algorithms, heuristics, and distributed protocols that are provably efficient; (iii) investigate the impact of imperfect knowledge on performance; (iv) validate the results via testbed deployment.

The project is expected to lead to fundamental breakthroughs in the design and performance of wireless networks for content sharing. The algorithms and protocols developed by exploiting double opportunism, and the theories underlying them, will have a significant impact on the wireless industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: In the recent years, we have witnessed a fast growth in the popularity and capabilities of mobile devices such as smartphones and tablets. These mobile devices have a lot of computational power and allow users to access, process, and share information (content) anytime, anywhere. On the other hand, these mobile devices have put significant stress on many of today’s cellphone networks (cellular networks), which are running at or near their peak capacities. Solutions involving additional cellphone towers (base stations) are very expensive and time-consuming. This calls for an alternative solution for sharing content in mobile networks - one that is faster to deploy and much cheaper than the current solutions.

 

In this project, we investigate how to exploit the key attributes of mobile content sharing environments to dramatically increase wireless network performance. Mobile content sharing has several salient features. Mobility of numerous users, rich content, and individual users’ ever-growing need for communication and computation capacity are the most prominent ones. Traditionally, mobility, content distribution, and scheduling in cellular networks have been studied in isolation.

 

In our research, we jointly consider two or more features. For example, our study shows that considering both the wireless channel and mobility simultaneously can achieve much better performance. In this project, we have been focusing on the following research tasks: (i) developing the theoretical foundations for increasing the capacity of cellphone networks; (ii) designing efficient algorithms to achieve the cellphone network capacity; (iii) developing robust wireless network protocols; and (iv) validating the research results via implementing the algorithms and protocols in software simulations and real mobile phones.

 

Broader Impact: The project results include fundamental theories, efficient algorithms, robust wireless network protocols, and implementations in software and mobile devices. The research results have been published in peer-reviewed, high-qualify journals and conferences. The results have significant impacts on the design of wireless networks and the wireless industry. This project provides training opportunities for both undergraduate students and graduate students, in science, engineering, and technology. The training will be valuable in their future careers. Several students of under-represented groups have been supported by this project. For example, one female Ph.D. student supported by this project became a tenure-track assistant professor at a university in the U.S.

 

The research results from this project have been included in undergraduate wireless courses and advanced wireless graduate level courses at both Temple University and Ohio State University. The research results have been presented in a number of international conferences. A dedicated webpage is used to make all the project results freely available to the community.
